column4: Hello, does anyone know if it's ok to cancel Gparted operations? It is resizing a windows partition I don't really want, if I damage my other partitions?
if you cancel a partition operation while it's in progress, in all likelihood bad things will happen
I don't care if it damages my worthless windows partition which it is resizing, but I can't have another damaged.
why didn't you make a backup before you started messing with partitions, like every guide tells you to?
and if i recall correctly gparted asks you to make a backup before doing operations as well
Because I wasn't touching my other partitions, moving my linux partition
so?
modifying partitions on disk = backup all important data on the disk or risk losing it
there is a restricted driver for it available in 8.10.  if you are using 8.04, you'll need to use ndiswrapper
the problem is, that she doesn't have internet access outside of wifi, and her CD drive is taken by the livecd. :(
i already told you the answer to your question.  If she doesn't have wifi she is out of luck.  she needs an internet connection to get it
would there be a way for her to put the .deb of it somewhere on her computer so she could get it when she was on ubuntu? Last I recall, Ubuntu does not recognize the mac filesystem.
ubuntu works with HFS+ fine from what i remember
read does at least, unsure about write
it wasn't working 3 months ago when I checked. :-/
Hm, ok, I'll try that.
Thanks.
because it can't know what is free space and what isn't
Ah. :-/ That would be a nice feature, it's a clean windows install on a 60 gb partition, so there's like 55 gb of free space.
it would also probably be longer to rewrite all of the inode tables so that everything could get rewritten correctly and not move free space
I kind of want it to just, delete itself now. :-P
it could
because you are dealing directly with partition tables, you can't do readahead or anything, so it's going to go slow, for safety's sake
I understand that. :)
